summary: A letter dated November 4, 2020, addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan, pleading for Ghislaine Maxwell to be granted bail. The writer argues her pre-trial detention conditions at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) are inhumane, citing lack of proper food, reading glasses, and family contact, and asserts she is not a flight risk or danger to the public.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The letter is addressed to her, urging her to grant bail to Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail plea; described as being held in solitary confinement at MDC since July, denied proper food and reading glasses, and argued to be no flight risk.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's case; the writer is appealing to Nathan to grant Maxwell bail.

events.title: Maxwell's Solitary Confinement Begins
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell placed in solitary confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

events.title: Bail Plea Letter Written
events.description: A letter is written to Judge Alison J. Nathan pleading for Ghislaine Maxwell's bail, citing harsh detention conditions.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The letter claims Ghislaine Maxwell has been in solitary confinement at the MDC since July 2020 and could remain so until July 2021.
The writer alleges Maxwell has not been fed properly, denied reading glasses, and had most written correspondence returned.
The argument for bail is that Maxwell is not a danger to the public and had prior opportunity to flee the U.S. before her arrest but did not.
The letter appeals to Judge Alison J. Nathan to use technological monitoring as an alternative to detention to ensure court appearance.
